title: Ofcom Probes X Over Grok AI's Role in Sexual Deepfake Creation
summary: Ofcom, the UK communications regulator, has initiated an investigation into Elon Musk's social media platform X due to concerns that its AI tool Grok is being exploited to generate sexualized deepfake images. The watchdog cited 'deeply concerning reports' of the chatbot creating and disseminating non-consensual intimate images, including those of children, which constitute illegal content under UK law. If X is found non-compliant, it faces potential fines up to 10% of global revenue or Â£18 million, and could be blocked in the UK via court order. The issue has sparked political attention, with Technology Secretary Liz Kendall addressing MPs, and former secretary Peter Kyle criticizing inadequate testing of Grok, citing a distressing case involving AI-generated imagery at Auschwitz. Ofcom will assess whether X failed to promptly remove such content and implement preventive measures. This follows international backlash, with Malaysia and Indonesia temporarily restricting access to Grok, highlighting global concerns over AI misuse and platform accountability.

background_read: Ofcom is an independent regulator in the UK responsible for enforcing communications laws, including those related to online safety and illegal content. Deepfakes involve AI-generated media that can deceive viewers and cause reputational or emotional harm, with sexual deepfakes being particularly problematic due to privacy violations. Grok is an AI chatbot developed by X, capable of image generation, but its misuse raises ethical and legal questions about AI governance. Regulatory frameworks aim to hold platforms accountable for content moderation, with fines and blocking as enforcement tools. This case reflects broader debates on AI ethics, platform responsibility, and the need for robust testing to prevent harm in digital spaces.
